Award.AwardTitle: A New Paradigm in Joint Registration, Analysis and Modeling of Function Data
Award.AbstractNarration:
The dual problems of registration and analysis of functional data are very important in statistical analysis. They play important roles in applications involving phase-amplitude separation of real-valued functions, shape analysis of curves and surfaces, registration of 2D and 3D images, and analysis of longitudinal data with values on nonlinear manifolds. The PIs develop a novel framework that will lead to statistically consistent functional analysis and will substantially improve algorithmic performances over the current methods. The key novelty is to use Riemannian methods and distance-based objective functions that are: (1) designed for measuring registration levels of functions explicitly, (2) studied in the quotient spaces of functions modulo the registration groups, and (3) formulated for ensuing statistical analysis/modeling. Here one represents registration variability by actions of the domain-warping groups on function spaces, chooses an appropriate Riemannian metric (such that the group actions are by isometries) and studies novel mathematical representations that enable statistical analysis under such metrics. The main advantage is that both registration and analysis, e.g, computation of mean, covariance, PCA, are performed jointly under the same metric rather than the current practice of using sequential and disjoint steps. Preliminary results on some subproblems including real-valued function registration and shape analysis of curves are shown to be superior, both empirically and theoretically, to the current approaches. The goal is to broaden this research to a larger class of registration problems with similar fundamental solutions.

High-dimensional functional data is becoming omnipresent in today's society and one needs to nonlinearly align such observations in time and space, in order to improve data analysis, statistical modeling, and inferences. This project represents a multi-disciplinary effort that will develop both basic statistical science and computational tools for registration of functional data. This, in turn, will impact such data-rich applications as development of accurate growth charts for children, gene expression analysis, face recognition using images and videos, detection and evaluation of brain disorders (e.g. Alzheimer) using medical images, and human activity recognition using surveillance video data. The novelty and potential high returns of this project come from the variety of tools utilized---from differential geometry and statistics to imaging science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main focus on this project was to develop efficient, computational tools for geometric analysis of object data (real-valued functions, curves, and surfaces). Two important challenges are handled: (1) data objects are nonlinear and can’t be analyzed using traditional multivariate statistical tools, and (2) observed data often lacks proper temporal registration, so that has to be incorporated in the solution.  We developed novel metrics, representation and associated statistical models for analyzing functions in an elastic manner, i.e. compare objects while simultaneously registering points on objects.  

Intellectual Merit: The main technical contribution of this project was development of fundamental frameworks for statistical shape analysis of several kinds of data objects: (1) Scalar functions. (2) Curves in Euclidean Spaces, (3) 3D surfaces, (3) Trees-like objects such as axons, and (4) Trajectories on nonlinear Riemannian manifolds. In each case, the PIs developed the required theory and efficient algorithms for comparing, averaging, summarizing, and statistically modeling object data. Using Riemannian approaches, they derived novel metrics with appropriate invariance properties that can focus on shapes of the objects and ignore nuisance variables such as rigid motion, scaling, and re-parameterizations.This led to efficient computer algorithms with superior performance in shape discrimination and quantification of shape variability.

Broad Impacts:

(1) Six PhD students graduated, three of them directly (partially) supported by this grant. This grant supported PI's research during the supervision of these students. They were trained with broad interdisciplinary research expertise, suitable for current and future research positions, and found jobs in academia and government research labs. Here is a listing of graduates along with their graduation years and jobs:  Jingyong Su (Asst. Prof. Texas Tech University, 2013), Qian Xie (Industry, 2015), Derek Tucker (Sandia National Labs, 2014), Darshan Bryner (Navy Lab, 2013), Michael Rosenthal (Navy Lab, 2014), and Zhengwu Zhang (SAMSI Postdoc, 2015). Many of them received best dissertation and best paper awards.

(2) Papers published in 20+ journal papers in both reputed Statistics journals (JASA, EJS, JSPI, Annals of Applied Statistics, CSDA) and applied journals (IEEE journals, Biology, Chemistry, Neuroscience, PLoS, etc). Also presented papers at high-level conferences. The PI presented one plenary talk at ICIP 2013 (1200+ attendees) and 2 keynote lectures at workshops, in addition to several conference, workshop and colloquia presentations. He also participated in a special issue of EJS on a related research topic and co-dited a Springer volume on "Riemannian Computing in Computer Vision", along with Prof. Turaga.

(3) Textbook finished: The PIs are in the process of delivering the final version of the textbook titled “Function and Shape Data Analysis” (by Srivastava and Klassen) for publication by Springer. This textbook is expected to be released in Spring 2016.

(4) Interdisciplinary Research: The PIs closely worked with researchers in other disciplines (biology, medicine, biochemistry, to develop advance computer implementations that can be used directly on their datasets. Examples include: shape analysis of anatomical parts for medical diagnosis, landmark-free shape analysis of leaves for specification, 3D face recognition using shapes of facial curves, human action recognition using range sensors,

(5) Technology transfer: Collaborated with biochemists at NIST on alignment of chromatography data using our framework. We developed collaboration with navy researchers at NSWC, Panama City, on underwater mine detection.
